Admittedly, I did not go through all of the 16 hundred comments, but I looked through about 1/4 of the matches to the word 'left' and did not see the explanation that I was looking for. It's probably in the other 3/4 that I did not look it. I saw explanations that fit my knee-jerk intuition, but applied backwards as an explanation or applied forward with the question of why it is not the left handed screw on the right side. The knee-jerk thinking would be to put the left handed screw on the right pedal, as having the foot, pedal, and bearing on the pedal screw would drag on the screw as the pedal is cranked by the foot and attempt to turn the pedal screw out of the crank arm. The logic behind that thinking is that the top of the crank moves forward, and resistance from the foot on the pedal moves it back, encouraging a right handed screw on the right side to slip that out, like using a wrench to turn it, but with much less force. However, that force, due to bearings and other considerations, this is a very small force as we look at the whole system.

The best way to understand is to think about the model with extremes. Get rid of the threads, and increase the gap between the shaft (would be the screw, but we got rid of the threads) through the center of the pedal, and the hole in the crank, or to think of a large tube with a thin rod in the middle as a substitute for this thought experiment. Now, without turning the rod, move it around in a circle so that it wobbles in the tube. You will see that it settles in with only two points of contact and is allowed to roll round inside. Now, recognize which way the rod turns as you wobble/roll it around. The rod turns the opposite direction to the motion of the wobble.

Now, as you add the threads back in, and close up the tolerances, giving it a better fit, you will recognize that the turning action of the rod will be less, but still present as the fit is not perfect and never will be for a wrench fit application. Move this thought experiment back to a pedal and you will see that each time you turn the crank you have given one full rotation of wobble without any noticeable force to turn in the direction of that wobble. The closer the fit of the threads and the screw to the hole in the crank arm, the more times you will need to pedal before the right handed screw comes out of the left crank arm, but it will come out. So, we switch it to a left handed screw and the problem is avoided. The right handed screw on the right side will try to wobble in the direction of tightening as you work the pedals, so no need to switch that to the less conventional left handed screw.

Take the right pedal as an example. It uses a right-hand thread, so turning the pedal spindle clockwise (CW) relative to the crank will screw the spindle in, counter-clockwise (CCW) will unscrew it.

Say you put the bike in a repair stand, grab the right pedal and gently simulate the motion of someone riding the bike (always keeping the pedal platform horizontal as if your foot were there). The body of the pedal will turn CCW relative to the crank.

Intuitively you would think this might help unscrew the pedal! But in reality the clamping torque of the threads will be far, far greater than any friction in the bearings could generate. Even if the bearings were to seize, it would be very difficult to unscrew the pedal (unless it was never tight to begin with).

Now consider someone riding the bike, putting weight on the right pedal. This applies a force perpendicular to the ground, no matter where the foot is in the pedal stroke. Relative to the crank arm, this radial force rotates CCW, which - via the process of mechanical precession - creates a CW torque on the pedal spindle (thus tightening it). The rotations on the left side are all reversed, so it must use the opposite threading to prevent the pedal from coming loose.

The logic on the pedals is wrong. While true that one of the left-handed threads is on the left pedal spindle, the forces acting on the spindle during normal operation (or forward pedaling motion) actually serve to unscrew the pedals (the right side pedal is right-hand threaded). The pedals' tendency to unscrew can be exaggerated by extremely fouled bearings or with a pedal platform that is seized onto the spindle.

It makes sense that you wouldn't want your pedals falling off, true! Alas, this is not the reason for why the pedal threads are the way they are. In the end, I also do not have a "why" for the threading. I've always defaulted to an explanation that says you would rather have your pedals too loose than too tight (for reasons of being able to remove a stuck pedal, save the more expensive crank, or counter intuitively - rider safety). The history of how the pedals are threaded likely lies in the fact that early bikes were all "fixed-gear" (meaning, amongst other things, that the pedals cannot stop rotating while the bike is rolling). I was a bike mechanic for 5 years throughout high school and a year after, so that bike question was TOO EASY for me!! ;D haha, but I have an idea of why the left pedal is left hand screwed (although I am not certain, so take this with a grain of salt)...

So when you pedal, the pedals are going the way they get tightened (i.e. the right pedal is going clockwise and the left pedal is counterclockwise.) but technically if you look at it, the threads of the pedals are going the opposite way. So basically when you are normally pedaling, assuming the pedals have no spindles, they should unscrew. So in all technicality, I am pretty sure it does not matter what way the threads go on a pedal, because the spindle makes it negligible (ever pedal backwards on a bike? The pedals remain in! Boom, point proven! Haha) so I have a different theory.

The reason the left pedal is reverse threaded is for production! As a bike builder, I found it to be MUCH faster to screw on a reverse threaded left pedal than a right hand thread pedal. All I had to do was put my pedal wrench on it and twist the crank! Where as if it was right hand thread it would go much slower because it would have to turn the whole wheel assembly. Plus I always worked with the right side of the bike facing me, and having a fast, freely spinning wheel right next to my face is sort of scary when I want to tighten a pedal.

So I hope I nailed this, but otherwise, I am excited to see what the real answer is!!

A spin motion induces a force vector along its axis in the same direction as given by the Right hand thumb rule.
Same thing would happen along the axis of the screw while pedaling.
This leads to a mild tightening effect for the Right pedal so RH screws are fine here
For the left hand side however the effect is an outward force along the screws axis directing the screw to fall off.
Using a RH screw here makes the gradual loosening and falling off easier.
LH screws don't negate the force generated along the axis. It just makes it difficult to loosen this screw.

If they both reach terminal velocity, their velocity is constant, meaning they are not accelerating. If they are not accelerating, then a force equal to the force accelerating them must be counteracting the accelerating force, gravity. The force in this case is air resistance. But the gravitational force on the larger ball is greater, as it is proportional to the mass of the larger ball. So, since weight is equal to air resistance, the heavier ball experiences more at terminal velocity.

Actually, the screw is on the left side not so that it won't come loose as you pedal, but so that it will if the bearing inside the pedal fail. If it were the other way, and the bearing failed (likely from rust) the pedal would tighten very quickly into the crank arms. This is an issue because not only is it extremely difficult to remove then, but it's also dangerous to the rider. If your pedal seizes mid pedal, you could hurt your ankle but would also lose control of the bike because all of the weight is applied to that point. It's better to have the bearing seize and begin unscrewing itself because then at least there is warning (it feeling loose) before failure. For this reason, pedal threads have grease applied to them during assembly. The same is true for the right pedal, but because of how the crank turns, it will work the same with a right thread.

A quick way to find an answer is to understand that when any object reaches its terminal velocity (v), the forces exerting on the object should nullify each other. Hence,
Weight of the object (W) = Upthrust (U) + Air resistance (R)
U is equal on both objects since they have the same volumes.
R = Viscous force exerted by air = 6 × pi × radius of the object (a) × viscosity of air (n) × ter. vel (v)
Therefore, R = W - U = 6(pi)anv
So, it's easily undertood that 'R' and 'v' are higher when the weight (W) of the object is higher.
Conclusion: Heavier the object, greater the resistance it confronts & terminal velocity it achieves.
PS: That's why ants don't get hurt when they fall from heights. Lesser the terminal velocity, lesser the rate of momentum conversion (force) when the ant hits the flow -> less (no) injury.

Hi Diana,
I never know which way via lefty loosey righty tighty as i could neve determine the reference start point for rotation, instead i just use the RH curl rule for a RH thread. LH threads are also used on combustible has bottles like acetylene, propane, mapp gas etc.

I'm an electrical engineer and diy'er do I'll use terms sometimes found in field theory to reference the face planes and join RH curl rule to RH threads; ie a rh thread obeys the rh curl rule and similarly a lh thread obeys the lh curl rule.

The way i think about pedal rotation is to put yourself in the reference frame of the crank as viewed in both cases with the bike frame behind the crank. such that both viewing planes point away from each other. Then transpose the pedal rotation into that reference frame. The slight difference in diametre of the pedal and crank threads along with the radially rotating force due to the push on the pedal will cause a precession so that the spindle will try to rotate opposite to the pedal rotation. Hence the spindle threads are cut to tighten the spindle into the crank in the opposite rotation as the pedal.

Let us consider the rh pedal in the crank reference frame as viewed from the plane that points away from the bike. The pedal is rotating counter clock wise. Hence the precession will cause a cw rotation of the spindle. This cw rotation must be into the crank so as not to loosen the pedal. CW in is RH thread via RH rule.

LH pedal as viewed from the lh crank reference frame rotates ccw. Therefore precession will cause the spindle to rotate cw. this cw rotation must be into the crank to tighten which is lh thread as given by lh rule.

I appreciate this is a very physicsy/engineering answer and not all will follow.

Imagine a right side crank and pedal, in the pedal is forward, crank is horizontal position. The pedal bolt is slightly smaller and loose in the crank hole, and as you push, the pedal bolt goes down to the "bottom" of the crank hole.
A quarter turn of the pedals later, (right pedal low, crank is vertical) the bolt is now at the "back" of the crank hole.
When you push down now, the loose bolt goes from the "back" of the crank hole to the new "bottom" of the crank hole.
As it rolls down the crank hole from the back to the new bottom, it feels a slight right-hand tightening of the bolt. Friction makes it roll, and not slide down the larger crank hole. If the pedal bolt is at all smaller then the crank hole, forward pedalling rolls the smaller bolt around in the larger hole in a RH tightening fashion.
On the left side of the bike, this action will loosen a normal right-handed thread. The fix is to make the bolt thread left-handed for the left side pedal.

Left hand screw is on the left pedal because when you cycle the pedal spins the opposite way to the cog that you're turning to keep it at the same position under your foot. When looking from the left side the cog will be turning anti-clockwise so the pedal turns clockwise, which would loosen the screw in the pedal upon acceleration if the screw was right-handed.
The left pedal (where your foot is) is turning on the arm in the direction that could loosen a typical screw.

The heavier one has the greater air resistance at terminal velocity. Two ways to get the answer, both fairly easy.
1. At terminal velocity, air resistance is equal in magnitude to (& opposite in direction from) the force of gravity on it (= its weight). So the heavier one automatically has greater air resistance, because it has greater weight.
2. The terminal velocity is greater for the heavier object, and air resistance increases with increasing air speed.

I'm pretty sure I heard the reason for the left hand thread on the left pedal is so that if the bearings wear to bind, the pedal would screw itself out rather than keep tightening and potentially stripping the threads out of the crank and ruining it.
But there's also a left hand thread on the right hand-side bearing cup in the bottom bracket of the bicycle - where the cranks attach and rotate in the frame. The cup retains the bearings with the axle rotating inside of it so as the cranks turn clockwise, the bearings translate this clockwise torque into an anticlockwise torque on the retention cup. The cup is left hand threaded (in the common British standard) so that it will only get tighter due to the force of the bearings, while if it were right-hand threaded (as it is in the Italian and French standards) the right-hand side cup unscrews itself over time. I think the thread design in the bottom bracket is stronger so there is no fear of the threads being pulled out by a tightening bottom bracket cup - the bottom bracket becoming loose and making the pedals flop side-to-side is far more likely to cause damage and make the bike unridable.

Heavy ball mass = M
Light ball mass = m
Apply F=ma to each:
Heavy: F=M*g
Light: F = m*g
g being a constant (9.81ms^-2 on Earth), this leaves the only affecting factor of resultant force to be mass. Lighter object has lower mass, hence a lesser force pulling it down.

Since both bodies are travelling at a constant velocity (terminal), resultant force = 0. This means without any external forces, force of air resistance = force of gravity. We've established the lighter object has a lower force of gravity, ergo it also has a lesser force of air resistance.

As a bike mechanic, I saw this day to day. As you pedal a bike, the pedals rotate forward, clockwise on the right and counterclockwise on the left. If the left pedal used a standard bolt, eventually it would loosen and unscrew itself. With a left-handed bolt, pedal motion only tightens it. This being said, the bolt isn't directly influenced by the pedal or else you would have a finite number of strokes. Instead, the bolt floats on bearings inside the pedal body. Also worth noting, there is a second place on many bikes where you find left-handed threads. On a threaded bottom bracket (where the crank goes through at the bottom of the frame) there are two bearing cups. The right (drivetrain side) bearing cup is also lefty tighty.

My (very thorough) solution:

Let F_1 and F_2 be the forces of air resistance on m_1 and m_2, with m_1>m_2. Assume that the gravitational acceleration g is the same for both spheres, which is necessary for the question to make sense without further context. At terminal velocity we get

F=W

from Newton's First Law of Motion. By applying Newton's Second Law of Motion to this, we get

F_1=m_1*g
F_2=m_2*g
F_1/g=m_1>m_2=F_2/g
F_1>F_2

Thus we conclude that the heavier sphere experiences the greatest force of air resistance.

Formula for Terminal velocity is:

(2 v g (d2-d1))/(9n)

Where v is volume, n is coefficient of viscosity of fluid, v is volume of object, d2 is density of object and d1 is density of fluid.

Everything is same in both cases except d2 (density). So, ball with higher density will have higher terminal velocity, since it has more mass in same volume.

Also, air resistance directly depends on velocity, so more drag on the metal ball.﻿

If an object is at terminal velocity, that means that the force of gravity is balanced against the air resistance. So, the object with the highest gravitational force acting on it (m*g), will also have the greatest force from air resistance acting on it. Since g is constant all we have to worry about is m, so the object with the higher mass (the heavier object) will have the greatest force from air resistance acting on it.

The heavier sphere will experience a higher force of resistance at terminal velocity. It will be moving faster and displacing more air in the same amount of time despite accelerating at the same rate. The force of acceleration is a function of the objects mass and the acceleration due to gravity (9.8m/s^2). Since the object is no longer acceleration due to air resistance (terminal velocity) both forces are equal and are a function of the objects mass.

Both objects have the same drag coefficient of 0.47 and are subject of a force of acceleration that is proportional to their mass. Terminal velocity is determined by this equation: D = Cd * A * .5 * r * V^2, where D is the force of drag when it is equal to M*9.8m/s^2 or the force of acceleration due to earths gravity. A is the reference air (cross section and it is essentially 1 in this situation) r in this equation is the density of air and is also a constant for this comparison. M * 9.8m/s^2 = Cd * A * r * V^2 or M *9.8m/s^2 = 0.47 * V^2 or simplified as V = ((9.8m/s^2 * M)/ 0.47)^0.5 If you plot this function f(M) = V you will see the relationship between the mass of an object and its terminal velocity if all other variables are equal.

bicycle peddles are attached to the crank arms by a single bolt which goes from the outside of the peddle into the crank arm.

When viewing the bike from the riders left side, the peddle it traveling counter-clockwise. So any friction applied to the bolt from the peddle will begin to spin the bolt counter-clockwise, loosening a standard, right handed bolt.

This is not true for the riders right peddle. When viewed from that side, the peddle travels in the clockwise direction (we mirrored our view of the bike around the plane that the bike sits in). Since the peddle is traveling in the clockwise direction, any friction will begin to spin the bolt clockwise, tightening a right handed bolt.

Scanned through about 100 comments and didn't see the pedal answer.  The reason is so the precession doesn't cause the pedal to unscrew.  Precession is caused by the pedal screw actually rolling around inside the crank threads.  This rolling action is miniscule, but over thousands of crank rotations, it's enough to release the pedal.  Direction of precession is always the opposite of the direction of rotation, hence left-handed thread on the left side.

Hi!
I knew about the left handed screw but if you asked me to guess probably would have said something to do with the handlebars.

The reason you use a left-handed screw on the left pedal has to do with tangential velocity. Both pedals are revolving in the same direction; this creates angular momentum.

Picture a space ship which has a shape similar to a bike tire, only 1000x bigger. Now imagine we are people walking along the flat inner edge of the tire. The angular momentum of the space ship is caused by centrifugal force (the space ship is rotating at a constant speed of 8 m/s). It would push us outward towards the edge of the tire and away from the center of the space ship. Voila; you have artificial gravity on a ship.

But what does that have to do with the original posited question concerning the left hand screw? Well, quite a lot actually. The constant pedaling would apply a force to one direction. In the case of a screw, you screw it right to get it tight (that's how we learned the proper directions).

So the tangential velocity would gradually, over time, start screwing one screw tighter while unscrewing the other screw. Thus, the bike makers had to thread a left-handed screw on the left pedal. Barring a few backwards pedals from time to time (do they even make reverse-brake bikes anymore? I'm old!), the two screws, left-handed and right-handed, will only tighten with each bike ride.

Hope that helps,

A physics professor.

P.S. I know someone will comment on how we remembered to tighten and untighten screws. That's just fine.

Now, there's two ways I approached the problem, and both of them produced the same results, so I'm quite confident in my answer.

1. When object reaches its terminal velocity, it experiences no more acceleration. According to Newton's 1st law of motion that means that the sum of all the acting force vectors is equal to zero. By extension that means that forces acting in opposite directions (like drag and gravitational force) are equal, meaning that:
Fd = m·g
where Fd - drag (force of air resistance), m - mass of an object, g - gravitational acceleration
In other words at terminal velocity air resistance is proportional to the mass of an object, meaning that heavier ball would encounter higher drag.

2. Brute force method - just plug it all in equations. You can calculate terminal velocity of an object with an equation:
v = sqrt(2·m·g/(ρ·S·C))
where v - terminal velocity, m - mass of an object, g - gravitational acceleration, ρ - density of fluid/gas the object is falling in, S - cross section area of an object, C - drag coefficient
We can deduce that terminal velocity is proportional to square root of an objects mass.
Now let's check out what the equation for an air resistance is:
Fd = 1/2·ρ·S·C·v^2
where Fd - drag, v - velocity of an object, m - mass of an object, g - gravitational acceleration, ρ - density of fluid/gas the object is falling in, S - cross section area of an object, C - drag coefficient
That means that drag is proportional to velocity squared. We already know that the heavier ball has higher terminal velocity, so this tells us that the heavier object would encounter more drag as well.
We can also plug in the terminal velocity equation into the drag equation and see what results would it produce:
Fd = 1/2·ρ·S·C·(sqrt(2·m·g/(ρ·S·C)))^2 = -1/2·ρ·S·C·2·m·g/(ρ·S·C) = m·g

We know that the mass of object one is greater than the mass of object two. Thus, the the force of gravity on object one must be greater than that of object two. Since terminal velocity is achieved when the net force acting on the object is equal to zero, the object with the larger mass must also experience a greater force of drag. As both objects experience the same fluid density, cross-sectional surface area, and coefficient of drag the only difference in their force of drag must arise from their velocity. Therefore, the object with the larger mass must also have a higher terminal velocity.

That means the heavier object will experience a higher force pushing down, which means it also experience a higher force pushing up when it reaches terminal velocity.

So the answer is the heavier object experiences a higher force of air resistance.

Q: which ball experiences the higher force of air resistance, once the balls reach terminal velocity?

A: The air resistance force is equal to Fd (Drag Force) = 0.5 Cd * density of fluid * Area * Velocity²

where Cd is the drag coefficient which depend of the body form. Since both spheres have the same form and size, both have the same Cd and Area, also the density of the air is constant in the problem, so only the term left is the velocity, the terminal velocity.

The terminal velocity is the velocity when the sum of the drag force is equal to the gravity force (neglecting the buoyancy force) i.e, m*g=0.5 Cd *density *A*V², from which you obtain V = sqrt[2*m*g/(density*a*Cd)]. Finally, the heavier ball has more mass, so, its reach a higher terminal velocity, then a higher drag force.

tl;dr: the heavier ball.

The pedal thing is easy. The pedals turn such that the top moves forward from the rider's perspective, and the only torque is in that direction. That means that on the right-hand pedal the bolt is torqued clockwise as you face the frame, and the left-hand petal is torqued counterclockwise as you face the frame. Normal bolts tighten clockwise, left-handed bolts tighten counterclockwise, and you don't really want your pedals falling off now, do you?

As for the sphere thing, the heavier sphere experiences more drag. Terminal velocity is the point where drag and weight, the downward force on an object due to gravity, balance out. The bike issue...

When examining (modern) bicycle pedals, you'll notice that they are plates (more or less) with an axle that has ballbearings. This allows the pedal to freely rotate. When you push down hard, e.g. put your weight on the pedal, you sometimes notice a grinding sound and feeling. This means that the insides of one or more of the ballbearings are being crushed.

Now imagine that these ballbearings are attached to something that isn't supposed to twist and turn, such as a crank. This is the part of the bicycle where forces from the pedal are transferred to the central axis of the bicycle, where the large chain wheel sits. This crank has to flex as little as possible to make sure your pedalling is efficient. This means it has to be fixed tightly to the central axis, as well as the pedals.

The most force exerted on the ballbearings, is when the pedal is on top, slightly in front of the central axis. Cyclists often put their entire weight on it, for faster acceleration. This also means that the ballbearings may start crunching and twisting, causing the force to be transferred to the mounting point of the pedal, i.e. the screwing part of the pedal in the crank.

Since we are pushing downward and forward against the pedal, the screw also moves in that direction, which means clockwise on the right pedal. The left pedal pushes in the same direction, but the crank is in the opposite direction, so the screw twists anticlockwise.

So if the screw on the left pedal was the same as on the right, pushing too hard on the pedal would cause it to loosen.

You can test this by using a plank and mounting two blocks (without ballbearings) on each side, at the end. Now rotate them, with the 'pedals' in fixed positions. You'll notice that one side will loosen up, while the other one tightens.

The heavier object will experience a higher force of air resistance.
The gravitational force is greater for the heavier object (F=ma). Both objects travel at terminal velocity. This means the gravitational force (downward) is equal to the force of air resistance (drag, upward). Terminal velocity is the equilibrium of these two forces.
Because the heavier object experiences a greater gravitational force, this means the force of air resistance must also be greater at terminal velocity.

The force of air resistance is:
F = 1/2 * (air density) * (drag coefficient) * (projected area of the object) * (velocity)^2

As all other things are equal in this example, this greater force can only be achieved by a higher velocity. So the heavier object will have a higher terminal velocity.

If they reach terminal velocity, Fz=Ff (Ff means force due to friction, Fz is force due to gravity)

Fz=m*g (g= ~9.81 m/s^2, which is the acceleration due to gravity)

let m1>m2 (so object 1 is heavier)

Then, at terminal velocity, Ff1=Fz1=m1*g>m2*g=Fz2=Ff2

So Ff1>Ff2.

So the air resistance acting on the heavier sphere is greater.

At terminal velocity there is no acceleration, so the net force equals zero (F=m*a). The 2 working forces are gravity on the spheres and air resistance. So if the net force is zero, gravity = air resistance. The heavier sphere has more mass, so gravity is higher on it (Fg = m*g), so air resistance on the heavier sphere is higher. Bonus thing: if air resistance is higher, the velocity is higher (air resistance is proportional to the velocity squared).

At terminal velocity the air friction and force of gravity cancel each other out

F = g * m

That means if the mass is higher, the gravitional pull will be higher as well.
Which in turn means that if the air friction increases when the gravitational pull increases, the increase in mass will also increase the air friction.

Conclusion: The heavier object will have an increase in air resistance over the lighter object

Here's why:
At terminal velocity, the upwards and downwards forces cancel out. Since the only two forces acting on either ball is gravity and air resistance, this means the force of air resistance is exactly equal to the force of gravity, but in opposite direction. Since force is proportional to mass, (Newton's second law, F = m * a) the heavier ball will experience a higher force of air resistance because of its greater mass.
